title: 112_s3343
content: The Act may be cited as the "Nicholas and Zachary Burt Memorial Carbon Monoxide Poisoning Prevention Act". Congress finds that carbon monoxide is a deadly gas produced by burning fuel, leading to poisoning and potential death. Unintentional exposure from vehicles and fuel-burning appliances in homes causes over 400 deaths annually. Installing carbon monoxide alarms near sleeping areas can prevent fatalities, and Congress should promote their purchase and installation. Congress should promote the purchase and installation of carbon monoxide alarms in residential homes nationwide to enhance public health and safety. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an approved carbon monoxide alarm is defined as one that meets the standards set by the Commission. A carbon monoxide alarm is a device that detects carbon monoxide and alerts at safe levels. The Commission refers to the Consumer Product Safety Commission. A dwelling unit is a room or suite used for human habitation. A dwelling unit is a room or suite used for human habitation, including single and multiple family residences. Fire code enforcement officials are officials of the fire safety code enforcement agency. NFPA 720 refers to the standard for carbon monoxide detection and warning equipment issued by the National Fire Protection Association. SEC. 4. ADOPTION OF CONSUMER PRODUCT SAFETY RULES. The Commission is required to publish mandatory consumer product safety standards for carbon monoxide alarms and gas detectors within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. These standards will take effect one year after publication. If these standards are revised, Underwriters Laboratories must notify the Commission, and the revisions will be incorporated into the consumer product safety rule. The Commission can revise consumer product safety standards for carbon monoxide alarms and gas detectors, with conditions for determination and publication. Rulemaking can be initiated to amend standards for safe operation. Standards are enforced under the Consumer Product Safety Act. For enforcement under the Consumer Product Safety Act, standards published by the Commission must be consumer product safety rules as defined in the Act. Grant program for carbon monoxide poisoning prevention. The Commission will establish a grant program to assist eligible States and local governments in preventing carbon monoxide poisoning by requiring approved alarms in dwelling units. Eligibility criteria include adopting laws or regulations mandating NFPA 720 compliant alarms and submitting an application to the Commission. The Commission will award grants to States or local governments prioritizing the installation of carbon monoxide alarms in dwelling units with fuel-burning appliances or attached garages. Priority will be given to those with a strategy to protect vulnerable populations. The grant program prioritizes installing carbon monoxide alarms in dwelling units with fuel-burning appliances or attached garages. States must have a strategy to protect vulnerable populations and may use funds to purchase alarms and train fire code enforcement officials. The grant program prioritizes installing carbon monoxide alarms in dwelling units with fuel-burning appliances or attached garages. Funds can be used for training, public education on carbon monoxide risks, and administrative costs. Administrative costs cannot exceed 10% of the grant funds, and public outreach costs cannot exceed 25%. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of Appropriations: $2,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2012-2016 for the Commission to carry out the Act. Unexpended funds after September 30, 2015, will be retained by the Commission. Commission Report: A report evaluating the grant program implementation must be submitted to Congress within 1 year after grants are awarded each fiscal year.
